sentence: Home Depot Inc. (NYSE: HD ) call activity is on the rise during Tuesday's trading session thanks to investors who appear to be moderately bearish on the home goods company and were willing to limit maximum profits on options positions to bet on limited upside during the near term.

At 11:43 a.m. EST, a block of 10,000 August 29 calls changed hands for 73 cents per contract (the bid price when the volume hit the tape), a block of 10,000 August 30 calls traded for the bid price of 44 cents per contract, and a block of 20,000 August 34 calls crossed the tape for four cents per contract, which was closer to the bid at the time of this trade.

The out-of-the-money ( OTM ) August 29 calls are home to current open interest of 3,000 contracts, the OTM August 30 calls are home to current open interest of 6,300 contracts and current open interest the OTM August 34 calls is 44,000.

This options action suggests the investor could have sold to close the 34-strike calls and collected a net credit of $1.17 per spread (selling both the August 29-strike and 30-strike calls), making the total credit on this trade $1.21 per contract.
The open call spread position will turn a maximum profit of the credit collected if the stock is trading between $29 and $30 at August options expiration.

Risk is limited to the downside in the unlikely event that HD shares are trading at zero at expiration, but theoretically unlimited to the upside if the stock rallies significantly higher than $30 when the calls expire.
It is possible the investor tied this options action to stock, which would turn this trade into a volatility play, but this article focuses only on the hefty call volume on the tape.
HD did not announce any news today, and the stock has dropped 36 cents, or more than 1%, to $27.40 so far on the day amid the broad-market strength.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
